	(428,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Introduction:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;83%&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot; colspan=&quot;3&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The most fundamental skill needed to assemble any electronic  project is that of&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;soldering&lt;/strong&gt;. Soldering is the  process of joining two metals by the use of a &lt;strong&gt;solder &lt;/strong&gt;alloy, made by combining tin and lead in different proportions. It takes some practice to make the perfect joint, but like riding a bicycle, once learned is never forgotten. The idea is simple: to join electrical parts together to form an electrical connection, using a molten mixture of lead and tin (solder) with a soldering iron.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; &lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1.Certain factors that we need to bear in mind include:-&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Voltage:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Most irons run from the mains at 240V. However, low voltage types (e.g. 12V or 24V) generally form part of a &amp;quot;soldering station&amp;quot; and are designed to be used with a special controller made by the same manufacturer.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;33%&quot; rowspan=&quot;2&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;a toptions=&quot;width = 660, height = 440, type = flash, title = Soldering&quot; href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/v/Ep34RslFB-8&amp;amp;hl=en&amp;amp;fs=1&amp;amp;rel=0&amp;amp;hd=1&amp;amp;autoplay=1&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Wattage:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Typically, they may have a power rating of between 15-25 watts or so, which is fine for most work. A higher wattage does not mean that the iron runs hotter - it simply means that there is more power in reserve for coping with larger joints. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Temperature Control:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;the simplest and cheapest types don&#039;t have any form of temperature regulation. Simply plug them in and switch them on! Thermal regulation is &amp;quot;designed in&amp;quot;: they may be described as &amp;quot;thermally balanced&amp;quot; so that they have some degree of temperature &amp;quot;matching&amp;quot; but their output will otherwise not be controlled. Unregulated irons form an ideal general-purpose iron for most users, and they generally cope well with printed circuit board soldering and general interwiring. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nMost of these &amp;quot;miniature&amp;quot; types of iron will be of little use when attempting to solder large joints .A proper temperature-controlled iron will have some form of built-in thermostatic control, to ensure that the temperature of the tip of the iron is maintained at a fixed level and also guarantees that the output will be relatively stable.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Soldering stations:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;consist of a complete bench-top control unit into which a special low-voltage soldering iron is plugged. Some versions might have built-in digital temperature readout, and will have a control knob to enable you to vary the setting. The temperature could be boosted for soldering larger joints; these are designed for continuous production line / professional use. The best stations have irons, which are well balanced, with comfort-grip handles which remain cool all day. A thermocouple will be built into the tip or shaft, which monitors temperature.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Thermal Mass or Bits:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Select a suitable tip according to the thickness of the lead to be soldered. It is available with different diameters or shapes, which can be changed depending on the type of work in hand. Often, tips are iron-coated to preserve their life, or they may be bright-plated instead. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Thermal  Linkage:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A third factor to consider is thermal linkage. This  is the area of contact between the iron tip and the work. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nFigure 2 shows a view of a soldering iron tip soldering a component lead. Heat is transferred through the small contact area between the soldering iron tip and pad. The thermal linkage area is small.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;133&quot; width=&quot;200&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image002(1).jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Figure also shows a view of a soldering iron tip soldering a component lead. In this case, the contact area is greatly increased by having a small amount of solder at the point of contact. The tip is also in contact with both the pad and component further improving the thermal linkage. This solder bridge provides thermal linkage and assures the rapid transfer&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;of heat into the work.&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;133&quot; width=&quot;200&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image004.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;solder  gun&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;is a pistol-shaped iron, typically running at 100W or more, and is completely unsuitable for soldering modern electronic components: they&#039;re too hot, heavy and unwieldy for microelectronics use. Soldering irons are best used along with a heat-resistant&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;bench-type  holder&lt;/strong&gt;, so that the hot iron can be safely parked in between use. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nCleanliness, temperature, time, adequate solder coverage are the  key factors affecting the quality of the joint.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nAll parts - including the iron tip itself - must be&amp;nbsp;clean&amp;nbsp;and&amp;nbsp;free from&amp;nbsp;contamination.&amp;nbsp;Dirt or surface oxide is the enemy of a good quality soldered joint! Hence, it is an absolute necessity to ensure that parts are free from grease, oxidation and other contamination.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nAnother side effect of having dirty surfaces is the tendency for people to want to apply&amp;nbsp;more heat&amp;nbsp;in an attempt to &amp;quot;force the solder to take&amp;quot;. This will often do more harm than good because it may not be possible to burn off any contaminants anyway, and the component may be overheated. In the case of semiconductors, temperature is quite critical and applying such excessive heat may harm them.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Steps:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.1 Wetting:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;When the hot solder comes in contact with a copper surface, a metal solvent action takes place. The solder dissolves and penetrates the copper surface. The molecules of solder and copper blend to form a new alloy, one that&#039;s part copper and part solder. This solvent action is called wetting and forms the intermetallic bond between the parts.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;127&quot; width=&quot;194&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image006.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Wetting can only occur if the surface of the copper is free of contamination and from the oxide film that forms when the metal is exposed to air. Also, the solder and work surface need to have reached the proper temperature. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.2 Tinning:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;New tips must be tinned &lt;strong&gt;immediately&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;when used for the first time. Tinning components involves applying a thin coat of solder to the surface to be soldered. This greatly helps in achieving a good joint and should be done whenever possible. A continuously tinned surface must be maintained on the soldering iron tip&#039;s working surface to ensure proper heat transfer and to avoid transfer of impurities to the solder connection &lt;br /&gt;\r\nIt&amp;rsquo;s better to re-apply a very small amount of solder again, mainly to improve the thermal contact between the iron and the joint, so that the solder will flow more quickly and easily. Insert the components and splay the leads so that the part is held in place. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;  &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.3 De-Oxidation:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Scrape the Printed Circuit Board and lead of the component using steel wool to remove oxidation. Use a small hand-held file or scrape a knife blade or rub a fine emery cloth over them to reveal fresh metal underneath. After preparing the surfaces, avoid touching the parts afterwards if at all possible. To form the component properly&amp;ndash; check whether the component easily goes inside the PCB. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.4 Flux:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Flux removes oxides which arise during heating, and is seen as a brown fluid bubbling away on the joint.&amp;nbsp;Flux is a solvent consisting of natural or synthetic rosins to remove oxides on the copper surface. It is non-corrosive and non-conductive and will not affect the circuitry.&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;To make any good, solid joints, the components have to be both physically and chemically clean as the solder needs to actually get into the components not just on them. Scraping the leads of the components and dipping the leads in flux and apply flux on the pads of the PCB also helps to remove the surface oxides in the soldering process.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.5 Temperature  control:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Another step to successful soldering is to ensure that the&amp;nbsp;temperature&amp;nbsp;of&amp;nbsp;all&amp;nbsp;the parts is raised to roughly the same level before applying solder. Imagine, for instance, trying to solder a resistor into place on a printed circuit board: it&#039;s far better to heat&amp;nbsp;both the copper p.c.b.&amp;nbsp;and&amp;nbsp;the resistor lead at the same time before applying solder, so that the solder will flow much more readily over the joint. Heating one part but not the other is far less satisfactory joint, so strive to ensure that the iron is in contact with&amp;nbsp;all the components first, before touching the solder to it. The melting point of most solder is in the region of 188&amp;deg;C (370&amp;deg;F) and the iron tip temperature is typically 330-350&amp;deg;C (626&amp;deg;-662&amp;deg;F). The latest lead-free solders typically require a higher temperature.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.6 Time:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Next,  the joint should be heated with the bit for just the right amount of&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;time&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;- during which a short length of  solder is applied to the joint. Do&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;not&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;use the iron to carry molten solder over to the joint! Excessive time will damage the component and perhaps the circuit board copper foil too! Heat the joint with the tip of the iron, then continue heating whilst applying solder, then remove the iron and allow the joint to cool. This should take only a few seconds, with experience. The heating period depends on the temperature of your iron and size of the joint - and larger parts need more heat than smaller.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.7 Applying Solder:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; In general, the soldering iron tip should be applied to the maximum mass point of the joint. This will permit the rapid thermal elevation of the parts to be soldered. Molten solder always flows from the cooler area toward the hotter one. Before solder is applied; the surface temperature of the parts being soldered must be elevated above the solder melting point. Never melt the solder against the iron tip and allow it to flow onto a surface cooler than the solder melting temperature&lt;br /&gt;\r\nTo solder, place the tip of the soldering gun directly against the area to be soldered and carefully apply the hot solder to the area where the soldering gun touches the metal. Only apply the minimum amount of solder needed to set the connection; excess solder will run into the other components of your project. Never blow on the hot solder or try to use the connection before it is completely cooled. This will create small fractures in the metal joint and weaken the bond between pieces. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.8 Solder  Coverage:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The  final key to a successful solder joint is to apply an appropriate amount of  solder.&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Too much solder&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;is  an unnecessary waste and may cause short circuits with adjacent joints.&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;Too little&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;and it may not support the component properly, or may not fully form a working joint. How much to apply, only really comes with practice. A few millimeters only, are enough for an &amp;quot;average&amp;quot; p.c.b. joint.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.9 Post Solder Cleaning:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;When cleaning is required, flux residue should be removed as soon as possible, but no later than one hour after soldering. Some fluxes may require more immediate action to facilitate adequate removal.&lt;strong&gt; &lt;/strong&gt;Mechanical means such as agitation, spraying, brushing, and other methods of applications may be used in conjunction with the cleaning solution.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.10 Re-soldering:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Care should be taken to avoid the need for re-soldering. When resoldering is required, quality standards for the re-soldered connection should be the same as for the original connection. A cold or disturbed solder joint will usually require only reheating and reflowing of the solder with the addition of suitable flux. If reheating does not correct the condition, the solder should be removed and the joint re-soldered.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. EFFECTIVE SOLDERING&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3.1 How to make the  perfect solder joint:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     a). All  parts must be clean and free from dirt and grease.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Try  to secure the work firmly.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). &amp;quot;Tin&amp;quot;  the iron tip with a small amount of solder. Do this immediately, with new tips  being used for the first time.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd). Clean  the tip of the hot soldering iron on a damp sponge.&lt;br /&gt;\r\ne). Many  people then add a tiny amount of fresh solder to the cleansed tip.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nf). Heat  all parts of the joint with the iron for under a second or so.&lt;br /&gt;\r\ng). Continue  heating, and then apply sufficient solder only, to form an adequate joint.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nh). Remove  and return the iron safely to its stand.&lt;br /&gt;\r\ni). It  only takes two or three seconds at most, to solder the average PCB joint.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nj).Do  not move parts until the solder has cooled.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3.2 Characteristics  of a Good Connection:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A good solder joint has very few things to look for compared to a poor one. A good solder joint shows the following characteristics: &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a). Smooth &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Bright &lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Shiny &lt;br /&gt;\r\nd). Clean &lt;br /&gt;\r\ne). Concave solder  fillet &lt;br /&gt;\r\nf). Good wetting &lt;br /&gt;\r\ng). The end of the  wire or lead covered with solder &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;287&quot; width=&quot;398&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image008.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;4. DO&amp;rsquo;s and DON&amp;rsquo;TS&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Do&amp;rsquo;s&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;    a). Soldering iron should be  kept ON only when the soldering is being done. It should kept OFF, when it is  not used.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Remember that when soldering, the fumes in the solder are harmful to your eyes and lungs. Therefore, always work in a well ventilated area.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Hot solder is also dangerous. Be sure not to let is splash around because it will burn you almost instantly. Eye protection is also advised.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Don&amp;rsquo;ts&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; a). Don&#039;t use a big soldering iron and the big 1/4-inch, acid-core. Anything higher in wattage, like soldering guns will generate most of their heat by passing an electrical current through a wire. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Be careful not to apply your soldering iron for long periods of time. Otherwise, you can damage sensitive components or burn up a circuit board trace. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Do not use too much solder - a strong joint  relies on a good fit and a little solder. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nd). Don&#039;t settle for a poor joint &amp;ndash; if in doubt  start again.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. Safety measures:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;   a). Never touch the element or tip of the soldering iron. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). They are very hot (about 400&amp;deg;C) and will give you a nasty burn. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Take great care to avoid touching the mains flex with the tip of the       iron. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nd). The iron should have a heatproof flex for extra protection. An ordinary plastic flex will melt immediately if touched by a hot iron and there is a serious risk of burns and electric shock. &lt;br /&gt;\r\ne). Always return the soldering iron to its stand when not in use. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nf). Never put it down on your workbench, even for a moment.Work in a well-ventilated area. &lt;br /&gt;\r\ng). The smoke formed as you melt solder is mostly from the flux and quite irritating. Avoid breathing it by keeping you head to the side of, not above, your work.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nh). Wash your hands after using solder. Solder contains lead which is a poisonous metal.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6. Unreliable Solder Joints:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; Some examples of poor and therefore  unreliable connections to watch out for are: &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     a). Overheated -  de-wetting; lumps; dull; crystalline-like; looks as though sand has been thrown  into the joint. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Cold - poor  wetting; stretch marks between the pad and lead. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Fractured - poor  wetting; stretch marks between the pad and lead. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nd). Non-wetting -  solder balled up around the joint.&lt;br /&gt;\r\ne). Excessive solder  - lead or wire contour is not visible and the shape of the solder is convex.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nf). Insufficient  solder - hole is not covered; copper end is not sealed; it is not as wide as  the wire or lead.&lt;br /&gt;\r\ng). De-wetting -  usually excessive heat; solder balls up. This also occurs if an intermetallic  compound is involved. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Other defects to watch for include: &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;       a). Pinholes or  voids - from dust, dirt, flux gas, improper heat, or other contamination. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb). Lumps and large  holes - improper presoldering cleaning and outgassing from flux gas.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc). Damaged wire insulation - excess heat and/or wicking  of solder under the wire insulation. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(429,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; The following section provides an overview of the modules that are present in the application. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Soldering Controls:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The soldering Controls module consists of features that enable switching the solder gun on or switching it off. This feature is a toggle button enabling the user to choose between either of the control. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;   &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Component Toolkit:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Component toolkit module comprises of a set of components that are needed to be placed on the printed circuit board for soldering. These components include resistors, capacitors and diodes. These components are in the form of buttons. On clicking them and dropping at appropriate points on the PCB, the respective component appears.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Template Selection:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Template Selection module enables the user to choose the circuit board of his choice from the list of circuits available. For instance, if a user feels he can work on much more challenging circuits, he has an option to choose the appropriate board for his difficulty level. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;    &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Printed Circuit Board Layout:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Printed Circuit Board Layout module is the printed circuit board. The components are placed on the PCB for soldering. This module enables the user to place the components for soldering. In other terms, it is a container for components to be soldered.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Soldering Caution Kit:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Soldering Caution Kit module has a set of meters that constantly assist the user on his soldering. It comprises of the pressure meter, the tilt meter and the temperature meter. If the pressure goes way beyond the threshold, the meters indicate appropriately to the user regarding the error. He could then re apply the appropriate pressure and continue with soldering. Similarly other meters display and warm the user regarding the respective errors during soldering. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;    &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Application Control Kit:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Application Control Kit consists of buttons that are used to open, save quit the application.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(433,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Webliography:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.kpsec.freeuk.com/solder.htm&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.kpsec.freeuk.com/solder.htm&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.dixieline.com/soldering/Soldering.htm&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.dixieline.com/soldering/Soldering.htm&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.solderingguide.com/&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.solderingguide.com&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/soldering-101.html&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.dummies.com/how-to/content/soldering-101.html&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.toolingu.com/definition-660200-28290-solder-cleaning-paste.html&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.toolingu.com/definition-660200-28290-solder-cleaning-paste.html&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Experiment Mapping &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table width=&quot;85%&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;caption class=&quot;tableHeading&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/caption&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;tagExpHead&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Subject&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Courses&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;34%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Level&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(449,'&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: rgb(0, 0, 0);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Aim of the experiment:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;i) To determine acceleration due  to gravity, g, using a compound pendulum.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nii) To determine radius of  gyration about an axis through the center of gravity for the   compound pendulum.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: rgb(0, 0, 0);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Apparatus required:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Compound pendulum&lt;br /&gt;\r\nStop watch&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: rgb(0, 0, 0);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theory:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; A rigid body which can swing in a  vertical plane about some axis passing through it is called a compound or physical pendulum.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn fig.1 a body of irregular shape is pivoted about a horizontal frictionless axis through P and is displaced from its equilibrium position by an angle &amp;theta;. In the equilibrium position the center of gravity G of the body is vertically below P. The distance GP is a and the mass of the body is m. The restoring torque for an angular displacement &amp;theta; is &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;324&quot; width=&quot;204&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image0001(1).jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;143&quot; width=&quot;415&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/simple.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Where I is the moment of inertia of the body through the axis P. Expression (2) represents a simple harmonic motion and hence the time period of oscillation is given by&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;55&quot; width=&quot;308&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/time.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     Now I = IG + ma&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;, where IG is moments of  inertia of the body about an axis parallel with axis of oscillation and passing  through the center of gravity G. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;167&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;18&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;IG&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;15&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;=&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;28&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;mk&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;88&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;------(4)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;where k is the radius of gyration  about the axis passing through G. Thus &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;107&quot; width=&quot;504&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image0002(1).jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Comparing expression (5) with an expression of time period&amp;nbsp;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; style=&quot;width: 66px; height: 55px;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image002_0001(1).gif&quot; /&gt; for a simple pendulum suggests,&lt;img height=&quot;40&quot; width=&quot;64&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/moment.jpg&quot; /&gt;. This is the length of &amp;quot;equivalent simple pendulum&amp;quot;. If all the mass of the body were concentrated at a point O, along PG produced such that OP = (k&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;/a)+a, we would have a simple pendulum with the same time period. The point O is called the &amp;acute;Centre of Oscillation&amp;acute;.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Now since &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;86&quot; width=&quot;355&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/since.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Equation (6) has two values of GP (or a), which produces the same length l as the length of the equivalent simple pendulum. Since one of the roots for equation (6) is a, the other root a&amp;rsquo; will satisfy&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;218&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;40&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a + a&amp;acute;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;14&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;= &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;76&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;l&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;70&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;and&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td height=&quot;24&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a a&amp;acute;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;= &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;k&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;------(7)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;    &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Thus if the body were supported on a parallel axis through the &amp;lsquo;Centre of Oscillation&amp;rsquo; point O, if would oscillate with the same time period T as when supported at P.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nNow it is evident  that there are an infinite number of points distant a and k&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;/a = a&amp;acute; from G in   a rigid body. If the body were  supported by an axis through G, the time period of oscillation&lt;br /&gt;\r\nwould be infinite. From any other  axis in the body the time period is given by expression (5). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; The time period has a minimum value when a + (k&lt;sup&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;/a) is minimum, and that happen when a = k, and the corresponding time period is&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;52&quot; width=&quot;315&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image0006(1).jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;This experiment can be performed  with help of a rectangular metallic rod about 1m   long. This may be suspended on a  knife-edge at various points along its length through   circular holes drilled along the  bore at about 2 or 3 cm intervals. (Fig.2)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;188&quot; width=&quot;102&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image0007(1).jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(450,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The user can view the effect of Compound pendulum oscillation in different length. Click and drag the the pendulum bar to set a new initial angle. Move the length slider to adjust the length of the pendulum. Display of timer by selecting the option provided in the timer box.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(454,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For more info on one may read books, visit labs or check for other web contents. Here are some choices for reading material. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Books&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780070494732&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;9780070494732&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Kumar, Kumar. Engineering Mechanics. Oxford Oxfordshire: Oxford University Press, Year.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780070494732&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;2.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780435510787&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;9780435510787&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Hebborn, John and Jean Littlewood. Mechanics 5. New York: Harper Perennial, 2001.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780435510787&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;3.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780817641191&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;9780817641191&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Enns, Richard and George Mcguire. Nonlinear Physics with Maple for Scientists and Engineers. New York: Harper Perennial, 2000.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780817641191&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot;     &lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;div class=&quot;postConentPadding&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;link type=&quot;text/css&quot; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/caption&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;tagExpHead&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Subject&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Courses&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;34%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Level&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Physics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- Mechanics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- Collision&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Under Graduate (UG)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;/div&gt;\r\n&lt;/div&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(456,'&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Laser:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;b&gt;Light Amplification by Stimulated Emission of Radiation (LASER)&lt;/b&gt; is a mechanism for emitting electromagnetic radiation, typically light or visible light, via the process of stimulated emission. The emitted laser light is (usually) a spatially coherent, narrow low-divergence beam, that can be manipulated with lenses.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Beam Divergence:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The light emitted by a laser is confined to a rather narrow cone; but, as the beam propagates outward, it slowly diverges or fans out. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nAt the output aperture of the laser, the beam diameter is d. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nIts beam divergence angle &amp;theta;  , usually expressed in milliradians.  &lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn traversing a distance l . the beam diverges to a circle of diameter d&lt;sup&gt;&#039;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;sup&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;134&quot; width=&quot;363&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/pic1.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The beam divergence of an electromagnetic beam is an angular measure of the increase in beam diameter with distance from the optical aperture or antenna aperture from which the electromagnetic beam emerges. The term is relevant only in the &amp;quot;far field&amp;quot;, away from any focus of the beam. Practically speaking, however, the far field can commence physically close to the radiating aperture, depending on aperture diameter and the operating wavelength.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe divergence of a beam can be calculated if one knows the beam diameter at two separate points (Di, Df), and the distance (l) between these points. The beam divergence is given by&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;47&quot; width=&quot;308&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/pic2.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Spot Size:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;When light passes through circular openings such as pin holes or apertures, light spread out and diverges. When light is focused by a lens, the light does not focus to a geometrical point; instead it focuses to a tiny spot of some diameter, surrounded by alternate bright and dark rings. i.e, The spot size of the beam is the radial distance from the center of maximum irradiance or intensity to the 1/e2 points.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;182&quot; width=&quot;465&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/pic3.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(457,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.\tset a laser and a detector(for measuring the intensity)  on an optical breadboard.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2.\tAlign the laser beam  in such a way that laser beam can fall on detector.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n3. Fix a distance for the detector and take intensity measurements of the beam along a horizontal line passing the point with the maximum intensity.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n4.\tRepeat the previous step for different variants. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n5. Calculate the beam divergence by calculating the maximum intensity of the beam, which helps in calculating the beam spot size, at different distances from the laser with the help of the optical bread board.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(461,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;For more info on one may read books, visit labs or check for other web contents. Here are some choices for reading material.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780387290942&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780387290942&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;2.&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780471719748&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780471719748&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;3.&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780125839617&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780125839617&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;div class=&quot;postConentPadding&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;link type=&quot;text/css&quot; rel=&quot;stylesheet&quot; href=&quot;http://sakshat.amrita.ac.in/VirtualLab/css/default.css&quot; /&gt; &lt;style type=&quot;text/css&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;!--\r\n.tagExpHead {\r\n\tfont-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif;\r\n\tfont-size: 12px;\r\n\tfont-weight: bold;\r\n\tcolor: #333;\r\n\tbackground-color: #CCC;\r\n}\r\n--&gt;\r\n&lt;/style&gt;  &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;div style=&quot;padding-left: 50px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Experiment Mapping &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;table width=&quot;85%&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;caption class=&quot;tableHeading&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp; &lt;/caption&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;tagExpHead&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Subject&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Courses&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;34%&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Level&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;3&quot;&gt;Physics&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;- Mechanics&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;- Collision&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;Under Graduate (UG)&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;/div&gt;\r\n&lt;/div&gt;'),
	(442,'&lt;table cellspacing=&quot;1&quot; cellpadding=&quot;1&quot; border=&quot;1&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What is Oil-drop experiment?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Oil-drop experiment was the first direct and compelling measurement of the electric charge of a single electron. It was performed originally in 1909 by the American physicist Robert A. Millikan. Using a perfume atomizer, he sprayed tiny drops of oil into a chamber. Droplets could be observed at one side through a short focal distance telescope. To make droplets more visible he illuminated them from one side.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;At the top and bottom were metal plates hooked to a battery, making one positive and the other negative. Since each droplet picked up a slight charge of static electricity as it traveled through the air, the speed of its motion could be controlled by altering the voltage on the plates. When the space between the metal plates is ionized by radiation, electrons from the air attach themselves to oil droplets, causing them to acquire a negative charge. Millikan observed one drop after another, varying the voltage and noting the effect. After many repetitions he concluded that charge could only assume certain fixed values.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;By repeating the experiment for many droplets, he confirmed that the charges were all multiples of some fundamental value, and calculated it to be 1.5924(17)&amp;times;10&amp;minus;19 C, within one percent of the currently accepted value of 1.602176487(40)&amp;times;10&amp;minus;19 C. They proposed that this was the charge of a single electron.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;314&quot; width=&quot;406&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image002_0000.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Experimental procedure       &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Initially the oil drops are allowed to fall between the plates with the electric field turned off. They very quickly reach a terminal velocity because of friction with the air in the chamber. The drop is allowed to fall and its terminal velocity v1 in the absence of an electric field is calculated. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;54&quot; width=&quot;105&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image004_0000.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Where &amp;lsquo;dt&amp;rsquo; is the distance travelled by the oil drop and &amp;lsquo;t&amp;rsquo; is the time taken.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The field is then turned on and, if it is large enough, some of the drops (the charged ones) will start to rise. (This is because the upwards electric force Fe is greater for them than the downwards gravitational force Fw, in the same way bits of paper can be picked up by a charged rubber rod). A likely looking drop is selected and kept in the middle of the field of view by adjusting the voltage.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Now at terminal velocity the oil drop is not accelerating. So the total force acting on it must be zero. So the two forces Fe and Fw must cancel one another out (that is, Fe = Fw). This implies&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img height=&quot;46&quot; width=&quot;151&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image005_jpg.gif&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Once radius of drop,&amp;lsquo;r&amp;rsquo; is calculated, &amp;lsquo;m&amp;rsquo; can easily be worked out.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For a perfectly spherical droplet the apparent mass can be written as:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;55&quot; width=&quot;199&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image007_0000.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;36&quot; width=&quot;104&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image009.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;194&quot; width=&quot;222&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image013_0000.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Where q is the charge on the oil drop, &amp;rho; is the density of oil and E is the electric field between the plates. For parallel plates&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;41&quot; width=&quot;60&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image010_jpg.gif&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Where V is the potential difference and d is the distance between the plates. So the charge of a single electron &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;53&quot; width=&quot;122&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image012_0000.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;But  charge on a drop, Q= ne. &amp;nbsp;Where &amp;lsquo;e&amp;rsquo; is  the charge of an electron and n=1,2,3,&amp;hellip;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The simulation objective&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;       This experiment approximate the original Millikan Oil Drop Experiment .We will use this simulation to determine as much as possible about the electrical charges on the droplets.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(443,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;The simulation helps the user to understand the Robert Millikan Oil drop Experiment concept. Click start button to start the experiment to show the cross sectional view of Millikan Apparatus and telescoping view of Oil Drops.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;Select the type of oil drop atomizes by the atomizer and switch &amp;ldquo;ON&amp;rdquo; the voltage .Observe one oil drop and adjust the voltage applied to plates for maintaining the position of oil drop on the central horizontal cross wire of telescope. Note the voltage applied and switch &amp;ldquo;OFF&amp;rdquo; voltage to find the terminal velocity of oil drop by measuring the time of travel of oil drop between the two points (dt=0.05 cm).&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Variable Region&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;1. Voltage Button: Helps to switch &amp;ldquo;ON&amp;rdquo; and switch &amp;ldquo;OFF&amp;rdquo; the voltage applied to plates&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. Oil Type Combo Box: Helps to choose the type of Oil drops atomizes by the atomizer &lt;br /&gt;\r\n3. Voltage Slider: Slider helps to adjust the voltage applied to plates.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Measurement Region &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;1. Voltage Applied shows the voltage applied to plates in Volt&lt;/p&gt;'),
	(447,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For more info on one may read books, visit labs or check for other web contents. Here are some choices for reading material. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: block;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780495112402&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Serway, John. Let&#039;s Review. Oxford Oxfordshire: Oxford University Press, 2004.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780764126857&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot;           &lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Video References&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot;
